# Introduction



In 2023, NOAA Fisheries' Alaska Fisheries Science Center conducted two surveys within U.S. territorial waters of the Bering Sea: the eastern Bering Sea shelf bottom trawl survey and the northern Bering Sea bottom trawl survey. This is the 41st year of the eastern Bering Sea shelf survey and the sixth year of northern Bering Sea survey using standardized sampling protocols. A rapid response survey for the northern Bering Sea region was also conducted in 2018 using a modified spatial extent and sampling procedure and will not be covered here. The northern Bering Sea survey region contains 144 stations in an area bounded by the Bering Strait, Norton Sound, and the U.S.–Russia Maritime Boundary (Fig. (#fig-survey-points)). While the northern Bering Sea region has been surveyed sporadically in the past, 2010 is considered the survey's inaugural year because it was the first year the region was sampled using the same standardized sampling methods as the eastern Bering Sea shelf survey.

This region is a fundamental part of the Alaska Fisheries Science Center Loss of Sea Ice (LOSI) research plan, the primary purpose of which is to study the impacts of diminished sea ice on the marine ecosystem. In the NOAA LOSI research plan, the northern Bering Sea was identified as a region of critical importance for increased scientific monitoring because this marine ecosystem may be rapidly altered by the changing climate. This survey represents one component of a multi-faceted research plan to create a long-term time series designed to identify, as well as track, environmental and ecological change throughout the Bering Sea. Beyond the potential impacts of climate change, the scale and extent of fish and crab movements may also vary from year to year in response to a variety of biological or environmental processes. These movements cause changes in distribution and abundance that extend beyond the traditional survey boundaries (e.g., eastern Bering Sea) and ultimately create an additional need for survey data that provides comprehensive coverage of the entire Bering Sea. 


Here, we provide some of the results of the 2023 northern Bering Sea survey and compare these to observations from the 2010, 2017, 2019, 2021, and 2022 surveys. Continuation of the survey effort for a combined eastern Bering Sea and northern Bering Sea bottom trawl survey will provide more comprehensive information to investigate how fishes, crabs, and other bottom dwellers respond to biological and environmental changes on a large spatial scale over a multi-year time period. 

This document is for informational purposes only and does not necessarily represent the views or official position of the Department of Commerce, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, or the National Marine Fisheries Service. Not to be cited without permission from the authors. Final survey results can be found in our annual survey data report, which has not yet been published. Find the 2022 data report @2021NEBS2022. Detailed information on bottom trawl survey results for commercial crab species are discussed and analyzed in the AFSC Shellfish Assessment Program's annual data report [@SAPcrab2023]. 






::: {.cell fig.id='fig-survey-points' fig.asp='1.1538'}

The areas enclosed within the dark and light gray lines contain the eastern and northern Bering Sea shelf stations, respectively. The dots within each area indicate station locations. # Survey Design, Execution, and Analysis



The 2023 eastern Bering Sea shelf and northern Bering Sea bottom trawl surveys were conducted aboard the chartered commercial stern-trawlers FV *Northwest Explorer* and FV *Alaska Knight* (Fig. (#fig-vessels)). The eastern Bering Sea shelf survey started for both vessels on May 28, 2023 and ended on July 25, 2023 for the FV *Northwest Explorer* and on August 03, 2023 for the FV *Alaska Knight*. The northern Bering Sea shelf survey the FV *Northwest Explorer* started sampling on July 29, 2023 and ended on August 18, 2023 and the FV *Alaska Knight* started sampling on August 03, 2023 and ended on August 20, 2023. The northern Bering Sea shelf was divided into three strata (regions): one including the area north of St. Lawrence Island and Norton Sound and two others south of St. Lawrence Island separated by the 50-m (164-ft) isobath (depth contour). 






::: {.cell fig.id='fig-vessels' fig.asp='0.3846'}
![Fishing vessels FV *Alaska Knight* (left) and FV *Northwest Explorer* (right) contracted to conduct the 2023 eastern and northern Bering Sea bottom trawl survey.](00_community_report_files/figure-pdf/fig-vessels-child-fig-1.pdf){#fig-vessels-child-fig fig-alt='Fishing vessels FV *Alaska Knight* (left) and FV *Northwest Explorer* (right) contracted to conduct the 2023 eastern and northern Bering Sea bottom trawl survey.'}
:::


Scientists from the Alaska Fisheries Science Center, Alaska Department
of Fish and Game, International Pacific Halibut Commission, Bigelow
Laboratory for Ocean Sciences, Oregon State University, Southeast
Fisheries Science Center and volunteers from Washington College,
University of Alaska Fairbanks, and Stanford participated in the survey.

The northern Bering Sea survey was designed as a continuation of the systematic 20 × 20 nautical mile (nmi) sampling grid established for the annual eastern Bering Sea shelf survey. The northern Bering Sea survey contains 144 stations distributed throughout the 57,980 nmi^2^ (198,867 km^2^). The eastern Bering Sea shelf survey area contains 376 stations distributed over 143,733 nmi^2^ (492,990 km^2^). The addition of the northern Bering Sea survey expanded the overall survey coverage in the Bering Sea to 201,713 nmi^2^ (691,857 km^2^) and contains bottom depths ranging from 39.4 ft (12 m) to 255.9 ft (78 m). 



Both vessels sampled using an 83/112 Eastern otter trawl that has been historically used for eastern Bering Sea shelf, Chukchi, and Beaufort Sea surveys (Fig. (#fig-trawl-gear-alt)). This trawl is significantly smaller and weighs less than trawls used for commercial fishing in Alaska. Each trawl tow is ideally conducted for 30-minutes at 3 knots.






::: {.cell fig.id='fig-trawl-gear-alt' fig.asp='0.6667'}
![Diagram of the 83/112 Eastern trawl net.](00_community_report_files/figure-pdf/fig-trawl-gear-alt-child-fig-1.pdf){#fig-trawl-gear-alt-child-fig fig-alt='Diagram of the 83/112 Eastern trawl net.'}
:::

Catches were sorted and weighed in their entirety. Fishes, crabs, and other invertebrates were identified and sorted by species to the greatest extent possible. Subsamples of predominant fish species were weighed, sorted by sex, and measured to the nearest centimeter (cm). For the predominant crab species, carapace width (snow crab) or length (king crabs) was measured to the nearest millimeter (mm). Samples of some species of fishes, crabs, and other invertebrates were also retained to gather additional information that included their size, weight, sex, age, reproductive state, genetics, health (condition factor), and stomach content/diet.

Trawl survey catch data were used to estimate catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE), population biomass, population abundance, population abundance by size class for measured species and population abundance by age class for species for which otoliths were extracted. CPUE can be used as a measurement of the density of a caught species. CPUE is the estimated catch of organisms caught (in kilograms (kg) or number of individuals) per amount of effort (generally, a combination of gear type, gear size, and tow duration). For these surveys, effort is estimated as the area swept (area sampled). Mean CPUE values were calculated for the overall survey areas. Biomass and population estimates were derived for each survey area by multiplying the mean CPUE by the total survey area.

Environmental data, including water temperature in degrees Celsius (°C), depth in meters (m), salinity (parts per thousand), and underwater downwelling light were also recorded at each sampling station. Water column profiles of temperature and salinity at each trawl location were measured using a trawl-mounted conductivity, temperature, and depth profiler (CTD).



# 2023 Survey Results with Snapshot Comparisons to 2022

The cumulative area sampled by trawls at the 116 completed stations was approximately 1.49 nmi^2^ (5.1 km^2^), covering 0.0026% of the total area of the northern Bering Sea.

## Seafloor Bottom Temperature


Bottom temperature is a major environmental driver that influences the
distribution of fishes, crabs, and other invertebrates on the Bering Sea
shelf (Figs. (#fig-mean-temperature) and
(#fig-cold-pool-area)). The highly variable annual bottom
temperatures are related to changes in the extent of the summer cold
pool, defined as the areal extent of bottom temperatures below 2°C
(35.6°F) on the eastern Bering Sea shelf. The size of the cold pool each
summer depends on the extent of sea ice cover during the preceding
winter and the timing of its retreat during the spring and early summer.
During the coldest years, the cold pool has extended across the middle
shelf from the northern edge of the eastern Bering Sea survey area and
into Bristol Bay and near the Alaska Peninsula.

Subarctic fish and invertebrate species tend to avoid areas with cold
bottom temperatures (below 0°C (32°C) or 1°C (33.8°C), depending on the
species). Therefore, the size and location of the cold pool can affect
the migration of species across the eastern Bering Sea shelf and between
the eastern and northern Bering Sea shelf. Cold temperatures may also
provide a habitat refuge for cold-adapted Arctic species. During warm
years, Arctic species may be forced to adapt to unfavorable conditions
or redistribute due to the reduction in available cold pool habitat.
Temperature data from the northern Bering Sea surveys helps improve
understanding of how changes in bottom temperature affect the
distribution and migration of fishes, crabs, and other invertebrates.

The 2023 mean eastern Bering Sea shelf bottom temperature was 2.6°C
(36.5°F), which is near the 2.5°C (36.5°F) time-series average from 1982
to 2022 (Fig. (#fig-mean-temperature)). The near-average bottom
temperature in 2022 represents a departure from recent years
(2016--2021) that have had four of the five warmest years in the 40-year
time series. The 2022 mean eastern Bering Sea shelf surface temperature
was near the times-series average, but slightly warmer than the mean
surface temperature in 2021 (Fig. (#fig-mean-temperature)). Over
the 40-year time series (1982--2022) of the eastern Bering Sea shelf
bottom trawl survey, annual mean summer bottom temperatures were
variable, ranging from 0.7°C (33.3°F) to 4.4°C (39.9°F; Fig.
(#fig-mean-temperature)). During the last 15 years, bottom
temperatures from 2006-2013 were colder than average ("cold stanza"),
while 2014-2019 and 2021 were warmer than average ("warm stanza"; Fig.
(#fig-mean-temperature)).

The areal extent of the cold pool in the eastern Bering Sea has varied
greatly in size, from 6,150 km2 (1,793 nmi2) in 2018 to 385,975 km2
(112,532 nmi2) in 1999, respectively comprising 1.2% to 78.2% of eastern
Bering Sea shelf area (Fig. (#fig-cold-pool-area). In 2022, the
cold pool covered 36.2% of the eastern Bering Sea shelf survey area
(52,079 nmi2; 178,625 km2; Fig. (#fig-cold-pool-area). The areal
extent of bottom temperatures below 0°C and 1°C were near their time
series averages.

The mean northern Bering Sea bottom temperature in 2022 was 3.9°C
(39.1°F), which was essentially equal to the mean bottom temperature in
2021 (Fig. (#fig-temperature-bt-2)). The mean northern Bering
Sea surface temperature was 8.1°C (46.5°F), slightly cooler than the
mean surface temperature in 2021 (Fig. (#fig-mean-temperature)).
Bottom temperatures measured during the 2022 northern Bering Sea survey
ranged from -1.7°C to 12°C (Fig. (#fig-temperature-bt-2)) and
sea surface temperatures ranged from 0.7°C to 14.2°C (Fig.
(#fig-temperature-st-2)). In 2022, surface temperatures above
10°C were recorded in only 3% of the northern Bering Sea survey area,
which was less than in past years, when temperatures above 10°C were
recorded in 5-39% of the northern Bering Sea area (Fig.
(#fig-temperature-st-2)). Evidence of upwelling was observed in
the Chirikov Basin south of Bering Strait, as indicated by surface
temperatures below 0°C (32.0°F; Fig. (#fig-temperature-st-2)).

The extent of the 2022 cold pool was similar to the most recent
near-average year in 2017, but considerably larger than in 2019 and
2021. The cold pool covered nearly the entire middle shelf between 50 m
and 100 m bottom depths, north of 57 °N (Fig.
(#fig-temperature-bt-2)). Similar to 2017, the cold pool likely
did not pose a major temperature barrier to the northward migration of
mobile subarctic species from the eastern Bering Sea shelf to the
northern Bering Sea, such as walleye pollock and Pacific cod. The
coldest bottom temperatures (below -1°C) were observed in the Chirikov
Basin, along the U.S.-Russia Maritime Boundary. This area had extremely
cold bottom temperatures even during recent extremely warm years (2018
and 2019), but the size of this cold patch increased in 2021 and again
in 2022.

## Survey Data and Specimen Collections



From the EBS and NBS shelf trawl surveys, length measurements were collected from 174,680 individual fish representing 50 fish taxa. Additionally, 7,831 otolith age structure samples were collected from 10 taxa; 6,409 stomach samples were collected from six taxa; 222 fat-meter condition samples were collected from Pacific cod and walleye pollock; 162 genetic fin clip samples were collected from four taxa, and three genetic samples were collected from Pacific sleeper shark. 

## Estimates of Fishes and Invertebrates



In 2023, the total bottom-dwelling organismal biomass of the EBS shelf was estimated at 12 million metric tons (t) and the NBS shelf was estimated at 2.9 million t. Previously, the total bottom-dwelling animal biomass of the 2022 EBS shelf was estimated at 14.7 million t and 2022 NBS shelf was estimated at 3.4 million t. The percent change in biomass varied by fish and invertebrate taxon (Table (#tab-majortaxa-pchange-NBS)). 


In the EBS between 2022 and 2023, nine fishes and four invertebrates experienced decreasing biomass, three fishes and two invertebrates experienced increasing biomass, and 13 fishes and 11 invertebrates experienced no notable change in biomass within ± 25% change from the previous survey year. Prominent organisms that exhibited the largest decreases in biomass included Arctic cod (-98.0%), saffron cod (-85.9%), Pacific herring (-76.0%), other poachers (-73.7%), Neptune whelks (-47.3%), other flatfishes (-42.6%), and other tunicates (-25.0%; Table (#tab-majortaxa-pchange-NBS)). Prominent organisms that exhibited the largest increases in biomass included snailfishes (255.0%), corals (189.0%), smelts (102.7%), other sculpins (50.5%), and tanner crab (30.9%). In the NBS between 2022 and 2023, eight fishes and six invertebrates experienced decreasing biomass, four fishes and four invertebrates experienced increasing biomass, and 13 fishes and seven invertebrates experienced no notable change in biomass. Prominent organisms that exhibited the largest decreases in biomass included Arctic cod (-91.1%), Pacific herring (-88.7%), other flatfishes (-85.5%), all sea anemones (-77.0%), tanner crab (-69.8%), and other crabs (-65.1%). Prominent organisms that exhibited the largest increases in biomass included other worms (492.5%), snailfishes (159.1%), eelpouts (129.5%), jellyfish (104.3%), smelts (41.3%), and red king crab (39.5%). 



NBS survey catches were generally smaller than those from the EBS. Distributions of many predominant species extended throughout much of both survey regions. Several key species were found in the NBS in greater numbers than the EBS, including Arctic cod, Neptune whelks, Pacific capelin, blue king crab, saffron cod, sea urchins, shorthorn sculpin, smelts, snow crab, and variegated snailfish.



In 2023, 50% of the total estimated biomass in the northern Bering Sea was comprised of yellowfin sole (14%), walleye pollock (13%), purple-orange sea star (11%), Alaska plaice (11%), and Neptune whelks (5%). Previously in 2022, 50% of the estimated biomass was comprised of yellowfin sole (16%), walleye pollock (11%), purple-orange sea star (9%), Alaska plaice (9%), and Neptune whelks (6%). 

Saffron cod and Arctic cod accounted for 1.3% of the total biomass in 2023 and 0.8% of the total biomass in 2022. Invertebrates (i.e., shrimps, sea squirts, sea stars, jellyfish, crabs, and urchins) made up 43% of the biomass in 2023 and 44% of the biomass in 2022.

# Summary Results for Select Major Taxa^[You can help us with this document by providing names in local language(s) and cultural or traditional uses for each fish and invertebrate species reviewed in this report.]

Survey results for select taxa are presented with a photograph of the taxon, maps of geographic distribution of CPUE (kg/km^2^), plots showing total population estimates at each length, and a short summary of results. Geographic maps of species distributions include both the eastern and northern Bering Sea survey regions to better illustrate patterns and trends in fish distribution and movement. For comparison, distribution maps and abundance-at-size plots show survey data for the 2010, 2017, 2019, 2021, 2022, and 2023 surveys. Detailed summary profiles outlining several of the species showing ecologically significant trends are discussed in Table (#tab-majortaxa-pchange-NBS).

## Walleye Pollock (*Gadus chalcogrammus*)

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](00_community_report_files/figure-pdf/spp-text-1-1-1.pdf)
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

:::

**Russian**: тихоокеанский минтай


The spatial distribution of walleye pollock was relatively consistent
throughout the northern Bering Sea survey area, with a small area of
relatively higher density in the Chirikov Basin just south of the Bering
Strait (Figure (#fig-dist-walleye-pollock-comm)).

Size distributions of walleye pollock in 2023 are similar to 2023 and
have two distinct modes (Figure (#fig-sizecomp-walleye-pollock-comm)). The total abundance
of adult fish \>40 cm is much smaller in 2023 than in 2022. However, the
total abundance of juvenile fish \<20 cm is much larger in 2023 than in
2022. Pollock in the 20-35 cm size range (representing 2-3 year-olds)
are generally absent or are in low abundance from survey catch samples
in the eastern Bering Sea (Figure (#fig-sizecomp-walleye-pollock-comm)) because they
typically occupy a position much higher in the water column where they
are unavailable to the survey trawl [@RN907].

## Pacific Cod (*Gadus macrocephalus*)

**Russian**: тихоокеанская треска

**Bristol Bay Yup`ik**: atigiaq

**Nunivak Island Yup`ik**: atgiiyaq

**Central Yup`ik**: centurrnaq

**Yukon, Hooper Bay, Chevak, Nunivak Island Yup’ik**: iqalluaq


The highest northern Bering Sea densities of this species were present
just north of St. Lawrence Island (Figure (#fig-dist-pacific-cod-comm)). Pacific cod
size composition in 2023 shows three distinct modes around 15 cm, 31 cm
and 61 cm (Figure (#fig-sizecomp-pacific-cod-comm)).

## Northern Rock Sole (*Lepidopsetta polyxystra*)

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](00_community_report_files/figure-pdf/spp-text-1-4-1.pdf)
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

:::

**Russian**: северная двухлинейная камбала

**St. Lawrence Island Yup'ik**: cagiq, sagiq


Northern rock sole are more abundant in the eastern Bering Sea shelf
survey than the northern Bering Sea shelf survey. The highest densities
of northern rock sole were observed north of the Pribilof Islands and in
Bristol Bay (Figure (#fig-dist-northern-rock-sole-comm)). The fork lengths of northern rock
sole measured during the 2023 northern Bering Sea survey were between 1
and 51 cm, with modes at 9 cm and 31 cm (Figure (#fig-sizecomp-northern-rock-sole-comm)).

## Bering Flounder (*Hippoglossoides robustus*)

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](00_community_report_files/figure-pdf/spp-text-1-5-1.pdf)
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

:::

**Russian**: северная палтусовидная камбала

**St. Lawrence Island Yup'ik**: cagiq, sagiq


Bering flounder were found north of 58°N, with highest densities found
north west of St. Matthew Island (Figure (#fig-dist-bering-flounder-comm)). In 2023, the
greatest number of Bering flounder individuals were around 10 cm in
length (Figure (#fig-sizecomp-bering-flounder-comm)).

## Alaska Plaice (*Pleuronectes quadrituberculatus*)

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](00_community_report_files/figure-pdf/spp-text-1-6-1.pdf)
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

:::

**Russian**: желтобрюхая камбала


Spatial distribution from 2017 to 2023 has been similar, with highest
relative abundance located south of St. Lawrence Island (Figure
(#fig-dist-alaska-plaice-comm)). In the most recent five years of the northern Bering Sea
survey, length modes were observed around 13 cm and 35 cm (Figure
(#fig-sizecomp-alaska-plaice-comm)).

## Pacific Halibut (*Hippoglossus stenolepis*)

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](00_community_report_files/figure-pdf/spp-text-1-7-1.pdf)
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

:::

**Russian**: тихоокеанский белокорый палтус

**St. Lawrence Island Yup'ik**: cagiq, naternarpak


Pacific halibut northern Bering Sea distribution in 2023 was similar to
that observed in 2022 and 2021, with the greatest densities of Pacific
halibut around St. Matthew Island (Figure (#fig-dist-pacific-halibut-comm)). The size
composition of Pacific halibut observed in the northern Bering Sea in
2023 had a mode around 56 cm and an overall range of fork lengths
between 22 and 108 cm (Figure (#fig-sizecomp-pacific-halibut-comm)).

## Alaska Skate (*Arctoraja parmifera*)

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](00_community_report_files/figure-pdf/spp-text-1-8-1.pdf)
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

:::

**Previous scientific name**: Bathyraja parmifera

**Russian**: щитоносный скат


Alaska skate distribution was relatively consistent across the eastern
Bering Sea shelf in 2023, except in the area north of St. Lawrence
Island to the Bering Strait, and in Norton Sound where no Alaska Skate
was encountered (Figure (#fig-dist-alaska-skate-comm)). Alaska skate is the most abundant
skate on the continental shelf of the Bering Sea. A similar size
composition of Alaska skate has been observed for all years of the
northern Bering Sea survey (Figure (#fig-sizecomp-alaska-skate-comm)).

## Plain Sculpin (*Myoxocephalus jaok*)

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](00_community_report_files/figure-pdf/spp-text-1-9-1.pdf)
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

:::

**Russian**: керчак-яок

**St. Lawrence Island Yup'ik**: nertuli


In the 2023 NBS survey plain sculpin were encountered along the coastal
shelf, from Nunivak Island to northeast of St. Lawrence Island. (Figure
(#fig-dist-plain-sculpin-comm)). The length composition of plain sculpin in 2023 was
similar to that in previous years, with a strong mode around 18 cm
(Figure (#fig-sizecomp-plain-sculpin-comm)).

## Shorthorn Sculpin (*Myoxocephalus scorpius*)

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](00_community_report_files/figure-pdf/spp-text-1-10-1.pdf)
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

:::

**Previous scientific name**: Myoxocephalus verrucosus

**Previous common name**: warty sculpin

**Russian**: европейский керчак

**St. Lawrence Island Yup'ik**: nertuli

**Inupiaq**: kanayuq


The highest densities of shorthorn sculpin in 2023 occurred north of
St. Lawrence Island and around St. Matthew Island (Figure (#fig-dist-shorthorn-sculpin-comm)).

The size distribution of shorthorn sculpin in the 2023 northern Bering
Sea survey ranged from individuals with fork lengths of 6 cm to 54 cm,
with modes at 8 cm and 20 cm (Figure (#fig-sizecomp-shorthorn-sculpin-comm)).

## Arctic Cod (*Boreogadus saida*)

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](00_community_report_files/figure-pdf/spp-text-1-11-1.pdf)
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

:::

**Russian**: ледовая (чёрная) треска

**Inupiaq**: Iqalugaq


The spatial distribution of this forage fish was mostly observed in
Norton Sound, as well as in a small area northeast of St. Matthew Island
(Figure (#fig-dist-arctic-cod-comm)). The fork lengths of Arctic cod measured during
the 2023 northern Bering Sea survey were between 10 and 24 cm, while
during the 2022 northern Bering Sea survey Arctic cod were between 6 and
48 cm (Figure (#fig-sizecomp-arctic-cod-comm)).

## Saffron Cod (*Eleginus gracilis*)

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](00_community_report_files/figure-pdf/spp-text-1-12-1.pdf)
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

:::

**Previous common name**: tom cod

**Russian**: тихоокеанская навага

**Inupiaq**: Uugaq


Saffron cod is considered to be a nearshore, bottom-dwelling species. It
was most abundant just north of Nunivak, with lower densities in the
waters off the coast of western Alaska, and into Norton Sound (Figure
(#fig-dist-saffron-cod-comm)). The fork lengths of saffron cod measured during the 2023
northern Bering Sea survey were between 6 and 42 cm (Figure
(#fig-sizecomp-saffron-cod-comm)).

## Pacific Herring (*Clupea pallasii*)

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](00_community_report_files/figure-pdf/spp-text-1-13-1.pdf)
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

:::

**Russian**: тихоокеанская сельдь

**St. Lawrence Island Yup'ik**: iqalluarpak, iqallugpak

**Inupiaq**: Uqsruqtuuq

**Central Yup`ik**: neqalluarpak


Areas of highest density of Pacific herring were located north of
St. Lawrence Island, along the Alaska coast, and in Norton Sound, as
well as along the U.S. Russia Maritime Boundary west and southwest of
St. Lawrence Island (Figure (#fig-dist-pacific-herring-comm)). Lengths of Pacific herring
have not historically been recorded during the eastern and northern
Bering Sea surveys because they are often caught in a small size range.

## Rainbow Smelt (*Osmerus mordax*)

**Russian**: Корюшка зубастая


Rainbow smelt distribution in the northern Bering Sea in 2023 was
primarily to the northeast and southeast of St. Lawrence Island, and
throughout Norton Sound (Figure (#fig-dist-rainbow-smelt-comm)). Lengths of rainbow smelt
have not historically been recorded during the eastern and northern
Bering Sea surveys because they are often caught in a small size range.

## Eulachon (*Thaleichthys pacificus*)

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](00_community_report_files/figure-pdf/spp-text-1-16-1.pdf)
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

:::

**Russian**: Евлахон


In 2023, no eulachon were encountered at any of the stations sampled in
the northern Bering Sea. Eulachon were most densely distributed
southeast of the Pribilof Islands in 2023 (Figure (#fig-dist-eulachon-comm)).

## Purple-Orange Sea Star (*Asterias amurensis*)

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](00_community_report_files/figure-pdf/spp-text-1-17-1.pdf)
:::
:::

**Russian**: Амурская морская звезда


In 2023, purple-orange sea star, also known as the northern Pacific sea
star, were observed in highest densities within the northern Bering Sea
survey area east of St. Lawrence Island. (Figure (#fig-dist-purple-orange-seastar-comm)).

## Red King Crab (*Paralithodes camtschaticus*)

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](00_community_report_files/figure-pdf/spp-text-1-19-1.pdf)
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

:::

**Russian**: Амурская морская звезда


Within the northern Bering Sea, red king crab occur predominantly in
Norton Sound (Figure (#fig-dist-red-king-crab-comm)). The carapace lengths of red king
crab measured during the 2023 northern Bering Sea survey were between
14.8 mm and 148.1 mm (Figure (#fig-sizecomp-red-king-crab-comm)). Detailed information on
bottom trawl survey results for commercial crab species are discussed
and analyzed in the AFSC Shellfish Assessment Program's annual data
report [@SAPcrab2023].

## Blue King Crab (*Paralithodes platypus*)

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](00_community_report_files/figure-pdf/spp-text-1-20-1.pdf)
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

:::

**Russian**: Синий краб


In recent years, the majority of blue king crab were distributed around
St. Matthew Island, the Pribilof Islands, and north of St. Lawrence
Island (Figure (#fig-dist-blue-king-crab-comm)). The carapace lengths of blue king crab
measured during the 2023 northern Bering Sea survey were between 40.7
and 129.4 mm (Figure (#fig-sizecomp-blue-king-crab-comm)). Detailed information on bottom
trawl survey results for commercial crab species are discussed and
analyzed in the AFSC Shellfish Assessment Program's annual data report
[@SAPcrab2023].

## Snow Crab (*Chionoecetes opilio*)

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](00_community_report_files/figure-pdf/spp-text-1-21-1.pdf)
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

:::

**Russian**: снежный краб


The highest densities of snow crab in 2023 were observed to the north
and south of St. Matthew Island (Figure (#fig-dist-snow-crab-comm)). The carapace
widths of snow crab measured during the 2023 northern Bering Sea survey
were between 7.5 mm and 126.7 mm (Figure (#fig-sizecomp-snow-crab-comm)). Detailed
information on bottom trawl survey results for commercial crab species
are discussed and analyzed in the AFSC Shellfish Assessment Program's
annual data report [@SAPcrab2023].

## Sea Urchins (*Strongylocentrotus* spp.)

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](00_community_report_files/figure-pdf/spp-text-1-22-1.pdf)
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

:::

**Russian**: еж

**St. Lawrence Island Yup'ik**: kemagnaq, uutuk

**Central Yup`ik**: kemagnaq, uutuk


In 2023, sea urchins of the genus *Strongylocentrotus* were present in
all six northern Bering Sea surveys (2010, 2017, 2019, 2021-2023), and
the highest densities were observed just north of St. Lawrence Island
(Figure (#fig-dist-urchins-comm)).

## Jellyfish (Scyphozoa)

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](00_community_report_files/figure-pdf/spp-text-1-23-1.pdf)
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

**Russian**: медуза


In 2023, jellyfishes had a relatively even distribution throughout the
northern Bering Sea, with a greater concentration found east of
St. Lawrence Island (Figure (#fig-dist-jellyfish-comm)). Jellyfishes play important
roles as both predator and prey within the Bering Sea ecosystem. Large
jellyfish blooms can have a significant effect on the survival of larval
and juvenile forage fishes, juvenile pollock, salmon, and the larval
stages of many invertebrates, including crabs [@RN998].

## Sea Onion (*Boltenia ovifera*)

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](00_community_report_files/figure-pdf/spp-text-1-24-1.pdf)
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

:::




Sea onions are stalked, solitary ascidians, which are widely distributed
in the North Atlantic, North Pacific, and Bering Sea. During the 2023
northern Bering Sea survey, sea onion density was around St. Lawrence
Island and north of Nunivak Island. (Figure (#fig-dist-sea-onion-comm)).

## Snailfishes (Liparidae)

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](00_community_report_files/figure-pdf/spp-text-1-26-1.pdf)
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

:::

**Russian**: Липаровых


In the 2023 northern Bering Sea survey, snailfishes were captured in the
waters surrounding St. Lawrence Island, as well as in Norton Sound
(Figure (#fig-dist-snailfishes-comm)).

The species of snailfish most commonly encountered during the northern
Bering Sea surveys was the variegated snailfish (*Liparis gibbus*), with
233 individuals captured in 2023. The other species of snailfish
captured during the 2023 northern Bering Sea survey were monster
snailfish, nebulous snailfish, festive snailfish, peachskin snailfish,
showy snailfish, and kelp snailfish.

Species information was added to this report by request of tribal
councils.

## Data Sources


The data collection efforts that constitute the annual Bering Sea bottom
trawl survey take place each summer by the Groundfish Assessment
Program's Bering Sea Team and the Shellfish Assessment Program. These
data are then extrapolated to catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE),
population-level abundance, population-level abundance by size class,
and population-level biomass estimates.

This document was generated using R and R Markdown. R is a coding
language and environment for statistical computing and graphics. R
Markdown provides a framework for reproducible, transparent, and
documentable report writing.

Many of the data sources and tools used to develop the plots and content
of this document have been developed by members across the AFSC's
Groundfish Assessment Program. These tools and public-serving data
products aim to increase transparency and accessibility to Bering Sea
ecosystem data. The *akgfmaps* R package
(<https://github.com/afsc-gap-products/akgfmaps>), developed by Sean
Rohan, was used for producing the species distribution plots and other
maps in this document. The *coldpool* R package
(<https://github.com/afsc-gap-products/coldpool>), developed by Sean
Rohan and Lewis Barnett, uses newly developed and reproducible
interpolation techniques to better understand changes in surface
temperature, bottom temperature, and the cold pool in the Bering Sea
[@RohanColdPool].

The catch, environmental, and location data collected and calculated
from the survey can be accessed directly and downloaded from the
Fisheries One Stop Shop data webportal
(<https://www.fisheries.noaa.gov/foss>). Users can interactively select,
view, and download data for this and other surveys conducted by AFSC's
Resource Assessment and Conservation Engineering Division. Data from
this and other fisheries-independent surveys are also used in the NOAA
Fisheries Distribution Mapping and Analysis Portal (DisMAP), which
provides easy access to information to track and understand
distributions of marine species in U.S. Marine Ecosystems
<https://apps-st.fisheries.noaa.gov/dismap/>.

To learn more about sustained participation of those fishing communities
substantially dependent on or engaged in the North Pacific groundfish
and crab fisheries, please review the AFSC's Annual Community Engagement
and Participation Overview (ACEPO) for Federal Groundfish and Crab
Fisheries of the North Pacific (https://shinyfin.psmfc.org/acepo/).
Additionally, the AFSC's Human Dimensions of Fisheries Data Explorer
(https://reports.psmfc.org/akfin/f?p=501:2000:17098464527744:::::)
provides access to data, data visualizations, and other tools for
understanding the economic and sociocultural dimensions of Alaska
fisheries.

Please note that this document is for informational purposes only and
does not necessarily represent the views or official position of the
Department of Commerce, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric
Administration, or the National Marine Fisheries Service. Do not cite
this document without permission from the authors.

## Acknowledgments


We would like to thank the many communities of the Bering Strait region
and their members who have helped contribute to this document. The
knowledge, experiences, and insights of the people of the Bering Strait
region have been instrumental in expanding the scope of our science and
knowledge to encompass the many issues that face this important
ecosystem. We appreciate feedback from those residing in the region that
are willing to share their insights, including the local names used for
the species covered by this document, identifying species of interest or
concern that should be included in this document, and participation in
an open dialog about how we can improve our collective knowledge of the
ecosystem and the region.
